segment.source: Lab 2b: Windows desktop apps and data: capturing changes
segment.target: Lab 2b: Windows desktop apps and data: capturing changes

segment.source: Lab 2b: Windows desktop apps and data: capturing changes
segment.target: Lab 2b: Windows desktop apps and data: capturing changes

segment.source: Lab 2b: Windows desktop apps and data: capturing changes
segment.target: Lab 2b: Windows desktop apps and data: capturing changes

segment.source: You can use audit mode to add Windows desktop applications and other data to the device.
segment.target: You can use audit mode to add Windows desktop applications and other data to the device.

segment.source: After doing this, we'll use the ScanState tool to capture these changes into a provisioning package so they can be used by the recovery tools.
segment.target: After doing this, we'll use the ScanState tool to capture these changes into a provisioning package so they can be used by the recovery tools.

segment.source: We'll also show you how to generalize the image, which prepares the Windows files to be captured and applied to other devices.
segment.target: We'll also show you how to generalize the image, which prepares the Windows files to be captured and applied to other devices.

segment.source: Step 1: Prepare a copy of ScanState
segment.target: Step 1: Prepare a copy of ScanState

segment.source: On your technician PC, plug in another USB key or drive.
segment.target: On your technician PC, plug in another USB key or drive.

segment.source: In File Explorer, create a new folder on the USB key, for example: D:ScanStatex64.
segment.target: In File Explorer, create a new folder on the USB key, for example: D:ScanStatex64.

segment.source: Copy the files from "C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10Assessment and Deployment KitUser State Migration Toolamd64" into D:ScanStatex64.
segment.target: Copy the files from "C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10Assessment and Deployment KitUser State Migration Toolamd64" into D:ScanStatex64.

segment.source: You don't need to copy the subfolders.
segment.target: You don't need to copy the subfolders.

segment.source: Copy the files from "C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10Assessment and Deployment KitWindows Setupamd64Sources" into D:ScanStatex64.
segment.target: Copy the files from "C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10Assessment and Deployment KitWindows Setupamd64Sources" into D:ScanStatex64.

segment.source: There will be duplicate files, it's OK to skip copying these files.
segment.target: There will be duplicate files, it's OK to skip copying these files.

segment.source: You don't need to copy the subfolders.
segment.target: You don't need to copy the subfolders.

segment.source: Prepare a device for image capture
segment.target: Prepare a device for image capture

segment.source: Get into audit mode
segment.target: Get into audit mode

segment.source: Boot up the reference device, if it's not already booted.
segment.target: Boot up the reference device, if it's not already booted.

segment.source: If the device boots to the Languages or the Get going fast screen, press Ctrl+Shift+F3 to enter Audit mode.
segment.target: If the device boots to the Languages or the Get going fast screen, press Ctrl+Shift+F3 to enter Audit mode.

segment.source: In audit mode, the device reboots to the Desktop, and the System Preparation Tool (Sysprep) appears.
segment.target: In audit mode, the device reboots to the Desktop, and the System Preparation Tool (Sysprep) appears.

segment.source: Ignore Sysprep for now.
segment.target: Ignore Sysprep for now.

segment.source: Verify drivers and packages
segment.target: Verify drivers and packages

segment.source: Right-click the Start button, and select Command Prompt (Admin).
segment.target: Right-click the Start button, and select Command Prompt (Admin).

segment.source: Verify that the drivers appear correctly:
segment.target: Verify that the drivers appear correctly:

segment.source: If you've added the sample driver, look for "Provider Name: DMI Test team"
segment.target: If you've added the sample driver, look for "Provider Name: DMI Test team"

segment.source: Verify that the packages appear correctly:
segment.target: Verify that the packages appear correctly:

segment.source: Review the resulting list of packages and verify that the list contains the package.
segment.target: Review the resulting list of packages and verify that the list contains the package.

segment.source: For example:
segment.target: For example:

segment.source: Step 3: Install a Classic Windows application
segment.target: Step 3: Install a Classic Windows application

segment.source: Install a Classic Windows application.
segment.target: Install a Classic Windows application.

segment.source: For example, to install Office 2013, put in a USB key with the Office installation program, open File Explorer and navigate to oemsetup.en-us.cmd.
segment.target: For example, to install Office 2013, put in a USB key with the Office installation program, open File Explorer and navigate to oemsetup.en-us.cmd.

segment.source: To learn more, download the Office OPK Update image from the Office OPK Connect site.
segment.target: To learn more, download the Office OPK Update image from the Office OPK Connect site.

segment.source: Step 4: Capture your changes into a provisioning package
segment.target: Step 4: Capture your changes into a provisioning package

segment.source: Capture the changes into the provisioning package, and save it on the hard drive:
segment.target: Capture the changes into the provisioning package, and save it on the hard drive:

segment.source: where D is the drive letter of the USB drive with ScanState.
segment.target: where D is the drive letter of the USB drive with ScanState.

segment.source: Note Optional: Delete the ScanState logfile: .
segment.target: Note Optional: Delete the ScanState logfile: .

segment.source: Prepare the device for the end user: Right-click Start, select Command Prompt (Admin), and from the command prompt, run the following command:
segment.target: Prepare the device for the end user: Right-click Start, select Command Prompt (Admin), and from the command prompt, run the following command:

segment.source: The Sysprep tool reseals the device.
segment.target: The Sysprep tool reseals the device.

segment.source: This process can take several minutes.
segment.target: This process can take several minutes.

segment.source: After the process completes, the device shuts down automatically.
segment.target: After the process completes, the device shuts down automatically.

segment.source: Boot to Windows PE and prepare to capture
segment.target: Boot to Windows PE and prepare to capture

segment.source: Plug in the lab USB key with Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE).
segment.target: Plug in the lab USB key with Windows Preinstallation Environment (WinPE).

segment.source: Turn on the device and press the key that opens the boot-device selection menu for the device (for example, the Esc key or Volume Up key).
segment.target: Turn on the device and press the key that opens the boot-device selection menu for the device (for example, the Esc key or Volume Up key).

segment.source: Select the option in the firmware menus to boot to the USB flash drive.
segment.target: Select the option in the firmware menus to boot to the USB flash drive.

segment.source: Warning If Windows begins booting instead of Windows PE, you must generalize the device again before capturing the image: After Windows boots, press Ctrl+Shift+F3 to enter audit mode.
segment.target: Warning If Windows begins booting instead of Windows PE, you must generalize the device again before capturing the image: After Windows boots, press Ctrl+Shift+F3 to enter audit mode.

segment.source: The device will reboot.
segment.target: The device will reboot.

segment.source: Generalize the device again: .
segment.target: Generalize the device again: .

segment.source: Optional: speed up the optimization and image capture processes by setting the power scheme to High performance:
segment.target: Optional: speed up the optimization and image capture processes by setting the power scheme to High performance:

segment.source: Find the drive letters by using DiskPart:
segment.target: Find the drive letters by using DiskPart:

segment.source: For example, the drives can be lettered like this: C = Windows; D is the lab USB key, and E is an external hard drive.
segment.target: For example, the drives can be lettered like this: C = Windows; D is the lab USB key, and E is an external hard drive.

segment.source: Note that some partitions might not receive a drive letter.
segment.target: Note that some partitions might not receive a drive letter.

segment.source: Optimize the image to take up less drive space (optional)
segment.target: Optimize the image to take up less drive space (optional)

segment.source: Convert the Classic Windows application and files outside of the provisioning package into pointer files which reference the contents inside the provisioning package.
segment.target: Convert the Classic Windows application and files outside of the provisioning package into pointer files which reference the contents inside the provisioning package.

segment.source: This is known as single-instancing the image:
segment.target: This is known as single-instancing the image:

segment.source: where C is the drive letter of the Windows partition.
segment.target: where C is the drive letter of the Windows partition.

segment.source: Warning Do not put quotes with the /ImagePath:C: option.
segment.target: Warning Do not put quotes with the /ImagePath:C: option.

segment.source: Cleanup the Windows files:
segment.target: Cleanup the Windows files:

segment.source: where C is the drive letter of the Windows partition.
segment.target: where C is the drive letter of the Windows partition.

segment.source: If DISM /Resetbase is a long-running operation, you can specify the /Defer parameter with /Resetbase to defer any long-running cleanup operations to the next automatic maintenance.
segment.target: If DISM /Resetbase is a long-running operation, you can specify the /Defer parameter with /Resetbase to defer any long-running cleanup operations to the next automatic maintenance.

segment.source: But we highly recommend you only use /Defer as an option in the factory where DISM /Resetbase requires more than 30 minutes to complete.
segment.target: But we highly recommend you only use /Defer as an option in the factory where DISM /Resetbase requires more than 30 minutes to complete.

segment.source: Step 5: Capture the image
segment.target: Step 5: Capture the image

segment.source: Capture the image of the Windows partition, and then copy it to the external drive or share:
segment.target: Capture the image of the Windows partition, and then copy it to the external drive or share:

segment.source: where C is the drive letter of the Windows partition and French and Desktop Applications is the image name.
segment.target: where C is the drive letter of the Windows partition and French and Desktop Applications is the image name.

segment.source: The DISM tool captures the Windows partition into a new image file.
segment.target: The DISM tool captures the Windows partition into a new image file.

segment.source: This process can take several minutes.
segment.target: This process can take several minutes.

segment.source: Troubleshooting: If you receive an: "A parameter is incorrect" error message when you try to capture or copy the file to the USB key, the file might be too large for the destination file system.
segment.target: Troubleshooting: If you receive an: "A parameter is incorrect" error message when you try to capture or copy the file to the USB key, the file might be too large for the destination file system.

segment.source: Copy the file to a different drive that is formatted as NTFS.
segment.target: Copy the file to a different drive that is formatted as NTFS.

segment.source: Step 6: Apply the image to a new device (optional, to be done in the factory process)
segment.target: Step 6: Apply the image to a new device (optional, to be done in the factory process)

segment.source: This represents the steps you'd use in the factory.
segment.target: This represents the steps you'd use in the factory.

segment.source: For the purposes of the lab, reuse the reference device for this.
segment.target: For the purposes of the lab, reuse the reference device for this.

segment.source: Prepare a place to store your files
segment.target: Prepare a place to store your files

segment.source: For this step, you'll need another USB key, or an external hard drive or network location that can handle large files.
segment.target: For this step, you'll need another USB key, or an external hard drive or network location that can handle large files.

segment.source: To format a separate USB key to accept large files: On your technician PC, go to File Explorer, right-click the drive and select Format.
segment.target: To format a separate USB key to accept large files: On your technician PC, go to File Explorer, right-click the drive and select Format.

segment.source: Select File system: NTFS, accept all other defaults, and click OK.
segment.target: Select File system: NTFS, accept all other defaults, and click OK.

segment.source: Then, connect the USB key to the reference device.
segment.target: Then, connect the USB key to the reference device.

segment.source: To use a network file share: On your reference device, map a drive.
segment.target: To use a network file share: On your reference device, map a drive.

segment.source: Example: net use N: servershare.
segment.target: Example: net use N: servershare.

segment.source: Note You won't be able to use the WinPE key.
segment.target: Note You won't be able to use the WinPE key.

segment.source: To make WinPE bootable for both UEFI and BIOS-based systems, WinPE formats the key using the FAT32 file system, which has a 4GB limit.
segment.target: To make WinPE bootable for both UEFI and BIOS-based systems, WinPE formats the key using the FAT32 file system, which has a 4GB limit.

segment.source: For other ways to get around this limit, see Split a Windows image file (.wim) for FAT32 media or to span across multiple DVDs.
segment.target: For other ways to get around this limit, see Split a Windows image file (.wim) for FAT32 media or to span across multiple DVDs.

segment.source: Copy C:WindowsWithOffice.wim to the storage USB drive or network share.
segment.target: Copy C:WindowsWithOffice.wim to the storage USB drive or network share.

segment.source: Skip this step if the reference device is already booted to WinPE.
segment.target: Skip this step if the reference device is already booted to WinPE.

segment.source: Boot to WinPE
segment.target: Boot to WinPE

segment.source: Connect the WinPE USB drive to your reference device.
segment.target: Connect the WinPE USB drive to your reference device.

segment.source: Turn off the device, and then boot to the WinPE USB drive.
segment.target: Turn off the device, and then boot to the WinPE USB drive.

segment.source: You usually do this by powering on the device and quickly pressing a key (for example, the Esc key or the Volume up key).
segment.target: You usually do this by powering on the device and quickly pressing a key (for example, the Esc key or the Volume up key).

segment.source: Note On some devices, you might need to go into the boot menus to choose the USB drive.
segment.target: Note On some devices, you might need to go into the boot menus to choose the USB drive.

segment.source: If you're given a choice between booting in UEFI mode or BIOS mode, choose UEFI mode.
segment.target: If you're given a choice between booting in UEFI mode or BIOS mode, choose UEFI mode.

segment.source: For more info, see Boot to UEFI Mode or Legacy BIOS mode.
segment.target: For more info, see Boot to UEFI Mode or Legacy BIOS mode.

segment.source: If the device does not boot from the USB drive, see the troubleshooting tips in WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive.
segment.target: If the device does not boot from the USB drive, see the troubleshooting tips in WinPE: Create USB Bootable drive.

segment.source: WinPE starts at a command line, and runs wpeinit to set up the system.
segment.target: WinPE starts at a command line, and runs wpeinit to set up the system.

segment.source: This can take a few minutes.
segment.target: This can take a few minutes.

segment.source: Format and set up the hard drive partitions on the reference device
segment.target: Format and set up the hard drive partitions on the reference device

segment.source: On the reference device, connect the storage USB key or network share.
segment.target: On the reference device, connect the storage USB key or network share.

segment.source: Find the drive letters by using DiskPart:
segment.target: Find the drive letters by using DiskPart:

segment.source: For example, the drives can be lettered like this: C = Windows; D is the WinPE USB key, and E is an external hard drive.
segment.target: For example, the drives can be lettered like this: C = Windows; D is the WinPE USB key, and E is an external hard drive.

segment.source: Some partitions might not receive a drive letter.
segment.target: Some partitions might not receive a drive letter.

segment.source: Format the primary hard drive, create the partitions, and apply the image by using the pre-made lab script:
segment.target: Format the primary hard drive, create the partitions, and apply the image by using the pre-made lab script:

segment.source: where D is the drive letter of the USB flash drive.
segment.target: where D is the drive letter of the USB flash drive.

segment.source: The script changes the power configuration for high performance, and then creates and configures the partitions based on the firmware on the PC (either UEFI or BIOS).
segment.target: The script changes the power configuration for high performance, and then creates and configures the partitions based on the firmware on the PC (either UEFI or BIOS).

segment.source: Shut down or reboot your device, either by holding down the power button for a full five seconds, or by using the following command:
segment.target: Shut down or reboot your device, either by holding down the power button for a full five seconds, or by using the following command:
